STATE OF MICHIGAN
DEPARTMENT OF HEALTH AND HUMAN SERVICES
GRETCHEN WHITMER ROBERT GORDON
LANSING
GOVERNOR DIRECTOR
November 7, 2019
Jennifer Tate
Livingston County DHHS
2300 E. Grand River #1
Howell, MI 48843-7577
RE: License #: CP470201250
Livingston County DHHS
2300 E. Grand River #1
Howell, MI 48843-7577
Dear Ms. Tate:
Attached is the Renewal Inspection Report for the above referenced facility completed on
11/05/2019. Due to the violations, a written corrective action plan is required. It should
be noted that violations of any licensing statutes rules and are also violations of the ISEP
and your contract. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
 How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
 Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
licensing statute and rule or section of the contract or ISEP citation.
 Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be
completed or implemented.
 How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
 The signature of the responsible party and a date.
Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, a regular certificate of approval
license will be issued. If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan,
disciplinary action will result.
P.O. BOX 30650  LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov  (517) 335-1980

Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (248) 975-5053.
Sincerely,
Pinkey Brown, Licensing Consultant
MDHHS\Division of Child Welfare Licensing
4th Floor, Suite 4B
51111 Woodward Avenue
Pontiac, MI 48342
(248) 860-3012
Enclosure
Steve Atwell, Program Manager
2

DIVISION OF CHILD WELFARE LICENSING

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
1.) The facility is in compliance with all applicable licensing statutes and rules.
2.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also an ISEP violation. Please note that
there are additional ISEP requirements that may not be included in section 1.
The facility is in compliance with all additional ISEP requirements except for
The following:
ISEP 6.30 Supervisory Oversight.
Supervisors shall meet at least monthly with each
Assigned worker to review the status and progress of
each case on the worker’s caseload. Supervisors shall
review and approve each service plan. The plan can be
approved only after the supervisor has a face to face meeting
with the worker, which can be the monthly meeting.
In 3 out of 11 service plans reviewed, a face-to-face meeting with the supervisor and
foster care worker was completed however the contact did not generate/link over to
to the service plans.
3.) Any violation listed in section 1 is also a DHS Contract violation. Please note
that there are additional DHS Contract/Policy requirements that may not be
included in section 1. The facility is in compliance will all additional DHS
Contract/Policy requirements except for the following:
DHHS Policy Medical Passport
FOM 801 – page
14-15
All medical information required by policy and/or law must be
provided to the foster parent. This includes copies of the
medical and dental examinations (if available) and the
information required in the medical passport. For children first
entering foster care, the initial medical passport must be
provided to the caregivers within two weeks of the child's
placement date. The actual date the caregivers receive the
medical passport must be documented in MiSACWIS. All
medical information within the medical passport must be current
and updated at least quarterly to reflect the child's current and
complete health information. Placement agency foster care
(PAFC) providers must provide a copy of the medical passport
4

to MDHHS monitoring staff as it is updated but no less often
than annually. Each foster care worker who transfers a child's
medical passport to another foster care worker must sign and
date the medical passport verifying that s/he has sought and
obtained the necessary information under law and MDHHS
policy. An updated medical passport is provided to: Legal
parents, if the child is a temporary court ward.
All medical and mental health professionals to whom the child is
referred and accepted for treatment.
-The child’s foster care provider at or prior to each
placement. This includes foster homes, relative placements
and residential facilities.
-Legal parents quarterly and at reunification, if the child is a
temporary court ward.
-All medical and mental health professionals to whom the
child is referred and accepted for treatment
One out of six foster care records reviewed contained medical passports that did not
contain verification that the foster parents received a copy of the medical passport
when the child was placed in the foster home.
REPEAT CITATION FROM RENEWAL 11/09/2017 AND INTERIM INSPECTION
01/17/2019.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The facility was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
Rule 400.12326 Borrowed Home
The agency is required to have a completed list of all children who were currently
placed in the borrowed bed home.
V. CONSULTATION
The facility was not offered consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
There was one incident of substantiated corporal punishment during this
licensing period.
SE2019C0627937 found the foster parents in violation of using corporal punishment,
of using physical discipline with the children in their care. The parents admitted to
using physical discipline on two occasions with the children and was in violation with
Rule 9201 foster parent qualifications. The foster parent took responsibility for their
actions and expressed remorse about how they handled these situations. The foster
parent was given a corrective action plan that involved trainings related to behavior
5

management, work with the foster child therapist on the knowledge of trauma
behavior, and develop a respite plan to ensure they are receiving support, agree to
not spanking and additional training on alternative methods of behavior
management.
The agency has submitted one acceptable corrective action plans not related
to maltreatment during this licensing period.
The agency submitted a CAP on 01/29/2019 for the Interim Inspection that was
completed on 01/17/2019. The CAP was approved on 01/29/2019. The agency is in
non-compliance with one citation of the CAP. The violations for the Interim
Inspection were as follows:
R 400. 12326 Borrowed home
R 400. 12327 Special evaluation
R 400. 12404 Placement
R 400. 12405 Change of placement
R 400.12418 Development of service plans
ISEP 4.22 MiSACWIS
FOM 722-068 Family Team Meeting
FOM 722-09 Supervisory Approval
FOM 722-08C Foster Care Parent Treatment Plan & Service Agreement
FOM 801 Medical passports
SRM 200 Personnel Training
It should be noted that there was a decrease in the number of cases in non-
compliance for this reporting period.
THERE WERE NO DCWL ANALYST CONCERNS/SAFETY ALERTS FOR THIS
REPORTING PERIOD.
6

VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules and/or ISEP requirements and/or contract/policy. Upon receipt of an
acceptable corrective action plan, it is recommended that Livingston County DHHS will
be issued a renewal of their regular license.
11/07/2019
________________________________________
Pinkey Brown Date
Licensing Consultant
Approved By:
November 8, 2019
________________________________________
Linda Tansil Date
Area Manager
